abstract.para: Keeping the correct time in a &vmguest; is one of the more difficult aspects of virtualization. Keeping the correct time is especially important for network applications and is also a prerequisite to do a live migration of a &vmguest;.

tip.title: Timekeeping on the &vmhost;
tip.para: It is strongly recommended to ensure the &vmhost; keeps the correct time as well, for example, by using NTP (see for more information).

sect1.title: &kvm;: using kvm_clock
sect1.para: &kvm; provides a paravirtualized clock which is supported via the kvm_clock driver. It is strongly recommended to use kvm_clock.
Use the following command inside a &vmguest; running Linux to check whether the driver kvm_clock has been loaded:
sect1.screen: &prompt.sudo;dmesg | grep kvm-clock [ 0.000000] kvm-clock: cpu 0, msr 0:7d3a81, boot clock [ 0.000000] kvm-clock: cpu 0, msr 0:1206a81, primary cpu clock [ 0.012000] kvm-clock: cpu 1, msr 0:1306a81, secondary cpu clock [ 0.160082] Switching to clocksource kvm-clock

important.title: kvm-clock and NTP
important.para: When using kvm-clock, it is recommended to use NTP in the &vmguest;, as well. Using NTP on the &vmhost; is also recommended.

sect2.title: Other timekeeping methods
sect2.para: The paravirtualized kvm-clock is currently not for Windows* operating systems. For Windows*, use the Windows Time Service Tools for time synchronization.

sect1.title: &xen; virtual machine clock settings
sect1.para: With &xen; 4, the independent wallclock setting /proc/sys/xen/independent_wallclock used for time synchronization between &xen; host and guest was removed. A new configuration option tsc_mode was introduced. It specifies a method of using the time stamp counter to synchronize the guest time with the &xen; server. Its default value '0' handles the vast majority of hardware and software environments.
For more details on tsc_mode, see the xen-tscmode manual page (man 7 xen-tscmode).
